DataElement.preferredName: Human Papillomavirus Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Spot Assay Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Type of ELISPOT HPV assay that was performed.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A highly sensitive immunoassay capable of detecting secreted materials from individual cells upon activation. If the material of interest is secreted in response to a particular stimulus, then the material will bind to a specific immobilized antibody. Binding is then verified and visualized by applying other antibodies that have been tagged in some way._The result of an action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A highly sensitive immunoassay capable of detecting secreted materials from individual cells upon activation. If the material of interest is secreted in response to a particular stimulus, then the material will bind to a specific immobilized antibody. Binding is then verified and visualized by applying other antibodies that have been tagged in some way.

Concepts.definition: A highly sensitive immunoassay capable of detecting secreted materials from individual cells upon activation. If the material of interest is secreted in response to a particular stimulus, then the material will bind to a specific immobilized antibody. Binding is then verified and visualized by applying other antibodies that have been tagged in some way.

Property.preferredDefinition: Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Human Papillomavirus Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Spot Assay Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Related to the specific type of ELISPOT performed

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-52

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-52
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.: A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce epithelial lesions. Infection with human papillomavirus-52 is associated with a high risk for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

Concepts.definition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.

A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce epithelial lesions. Infection with human papillomavirus-52 is associated with a high risk for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-35

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-35
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.: A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce epithelial lesions. Infection with human papillomavirus-35 is associated with a high risk for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E7 Human Papillomavirus-16

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E7 Human Papillomavirus-16
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Complexes with and inactivates Rb protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.: A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-16 (HPV16) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and is significantly associated with invasiveness. Progression from low- to high-grade neoplasia is often associated with the integration of the HPV16 genome into the host chromosome.

Concepts.definition: Complexes with and inactivates Rb protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.

A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-16 (HPV16) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and is significantly associated with invasiveness. Progression from low- to high-grade neoplasia is often associated with the integration of the HPV16 genome into the host chromosome.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-16

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-16
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.: A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-16 (HPV16) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and is significantly associated with invasiveness. Progression from low- to high-grade neoplasia is often associated with the integration of the HPV16 genome into the host chromosome.

A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-16 (HPV16) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and is significantly associated with invasiveness. PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-18

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Papillomavirus Transforming Protein E6 Human Papillomavirus-18
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.: A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-18 (HPV18) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and plays a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The virus integrates its DNA at specific chromosomal locations, such as 8q24 and 12q15. The use of molecular markers for HPV18 infection may allow the identification of patients with early stage cervical cancer and those at high risk for disease recurrence.

Concepts.definition: Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 protein resulting in disruption of cell cycle regulation.

A virus comprised of a protein coat (capsid) surrounding a circular, double-stranded DNA organized into coding and non-coding regions, which can induce skin and mucosal epithelial lesions. Human papillomavirus-18 (HPV18) has been directly linked to cervical cancer and plays a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The virus integrates its DNA at specific chromosomal locations, such as 8q24 and 12q15. The use of molecular markers for HPV18 infection may allow the identification of patients with early stage cervical cancer and those at high risk for disease recurrence.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Human Papillomavirus Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Spot Assay Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A strain of papillomavirus that can infect the skin and mucous membranes of humans.:A highly sensitive immunoassay capable of detecting secreted materials from individual cells upon activation. If the material of interest is secreted in response to a particular stimulus, then the material will bind to a specific immobilized antibody. Binding is then verified and visualized by applying other antibodies that have been tagged in some way.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A strain of papillomavirus that can infect the skin and mucous membranes of humans.

A highly sensitive immunoassay capable of detecting secreted materials from individual cells upon activation. If the material of interest is secreted in response to a particular stimulus, then the material will bind to a specific immobilized antibody. Binding is then verified and visualized by applying other antibodies that have been tagged in some way.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
